Puesto que los clientes que le están pidiendo estos productos son muy buena paga pero ella los cobra en plazos. Con este dinero María podrá comprar los pedidos para poder sacar dinero para los gastos de sus hijos. Con tu ayuda María podrá sacar adelante a sus tres hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Ermina

texts.en:
Ermina was born in 1982 and she is married. She has one girl, 7 years old. Her wish is to buy more stock because she already has a cow and heifer. In this way she can earn 300 KM, while her husband can earn about 300 KM monthly as a taxi driver.

This is her first loan in the MCO WWI in the amount of 600 KM and she wants to expand business by buying more cows and heifers.

loans.use: To buy more livestock.

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Florentina K.,  who is married with four children, aged 4, 8, 13, and 15.

In 2006 Florentina established a seamstress business, and now requests a loan of $350 in order to purchase additional stocks of material in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase material in bulk for her seamstress business.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima is a 48-year-old married woman. Her husband works in construction in Sarajevo and his monthly salary is 500 BAM. In addition, Fatima has two children, who live with her and her mother. This would be Fatima's second loan from MCO WWI and she would like to use this 1,500 BAM loan to buy chickens for fattening purposes and to generate additional monthly household income.

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa M. is 26 years old and is married with 3 children. She sews mainly women’s clothes. With her previous loan, she purchased sewing materials and a second hand sewing machine to start the business. She has many customers, but has no capacity to employ some one to assist her. She is, therefore, requesting a loan of Le.2,000,000 ($700 USD) to purchase 2 more sewing machines and to hire two more people to help with the sewing.

Hawa needs to expand her operations and hire people to work with her so that she can meet her production targets. She needs a loan to be able to do this.

loans.use: To buy 2 sewing machines and hire 2 employees

loans.name: Christine Kikoyo’S Group

texts.en:
Christine K. is 27 years old, married, with six children, ranging in age from 4 to 14. The five oldest are all in school.

Christine has operated a profitable grocery business for the past 7 years, selling matooke (green bananas), sweet potatoes, tomatoes, greens, fish and fruits in the market at Masanafu, a rural district of Kampala. She buys items from the Kasubi market, where farmers transport and sell their produce at relatively low prices. In turn, she sells the produce to her neighbours and the people in her community. She started her grocery because she needed money for school fees for her children.

With a loan, she will add new items to her business, such as charcoal. By selling more things and different things, her business will be even more profitable. She has successfully paid back more than 5 loans.

Christine would like to achieve a high standard of living: buying clothes for the children and having a good house. She wants to have enough money for all her children to complete their studies.

loans.use: Add new items to sell in the market

loans.name: Victoriano

texts.es:
Victorino is a 47-year-old sacrificed tailor. He married Lidia, who is 42 years old a long time ago. He has only one son who is 22 years old and helps him with his daily works, in addition to his studies at the university during the nights. Victorino tells us that he went through difficult times when he got married because he did not have a steady work, therefore he decided to go out to look for work abroad. He had a job in Buenos Aires for several years until one day he decided to return to the country to set up his own tailoring workshop with the money he saved during all this time. He has had his jacket-tailoring workshop for 12 years, which he delivers to a well-known store in the business. He mentions that he is doing well thanks to the fruit of his efforts and sacrifices. He has managed to construct his own house and to support all his family. His wish is to build a room at the back of his backyard where he would use for his workshop, because at present he is using his living room.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

Victorino es un sacrificado sastre de 47 años de edad. Está casado hace bastante tiempo con Lidia que tiene 42 años de edad. Tiene un sólo hijo que hoy día cuenta con 22 años de edad y le ayuda en sus labores diarias, además de continuar con sus estudios universitarios por las noches. Victorino comenta que pasó momentos difíciles cuando se casó porque no tenía trabajo estable, por lo que decidió salir a buscar trabajo fuera del país. Consiguió trabajo en Buenos Aires por varios años hasta que un día decidió regresar al país para montar su propio taller de costura con lo ahorrado durante todo ese tiempo. Hace 12 años que cuenta con su taller de confección de sacos, los cuales entrega a una conocida casa dedicada al ramo. Comenta que le ha ido muy bien ya que gracias al fruto de sus esfuerzos y sacrificios ha logrado construir su casa propia y dar de comer a toda su familia. Su anhelo es construir en el fondo de su patio un salón, el cual destinaría para su taller, debido a que actualmente trabaja en la sala de su casa.

loans.use: Buy different type of fabrics, buttons and zippers.

loans.name: Benkadi (‘Union Fait La Force) Group

texts.fr:
The seven women of the Benkadi group are all married with an average age of 45 and an average of 5 children. They live in big traditional families with at least one co-spouse, their husbands, and their children in a Peulh neighborhood (Peulh is a Mali ethnicity) known as Ouassila Wèrè (Ségou Prefecture, Republic of Mali).

This group arose out of a traditional association of mutual aid for times of social events (such as marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals) and for field work. They sell various articles such as tea, sugar, condiments, fruits and vegetables, cola nuts, and milk.

They buy their goods at the big open-air market of Ségou from wholesalers in the case of articles such as tea, sugar, and condiments. In the case of fruits and vegetables, they buy their goods in the villages surrounding the town of Ségou, notably Konodimini. The sale of these various articles is generally on a cash basis, or on credit, out of their homes or as ambulant salespeople, or at the market. Their clientele is generally men, women, and occasionally children. The very organized members of the Benkadi group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, from which they are requesting their first loan. With this loan they intend to buy 1 sack of sugar, 1 case of tea, a large quantity of condiments, a tray of cola nuts, and some sacks of fruits and vegetables.

Each of them expects to make a monthly profit of 7,500 FCFA (US$ 18) that they will mainly use to make repayments on the loan, investing the remainder in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les sept (7) femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec au moins une coépouse, leurs époux et leurs enfants dans le quartier peulh (une ethnie du Mali) appelé Ouassila Wèrè (Préfecture de Ségou République du Mali).

Ce groupe est issu d’une association traditionnelle d’entre aide mutuelle lors des événements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, circoncisions, funérailles) et dans les travaux champêtres. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers comme le thé, le sucre ; les condiments, les fruits et légumes, de la cola et du lait.

Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Ségou auprès des grossistes pour les articles comme le thé le sucre et les condiments. Pour les fruits et légumes c’est dans les villages environnants de la ville de Ségou notamment Konodimini. La vente de ces différents articles se fait généralement au comptant, à crédit, à domicile, de façon ambulante ou au marché. Leurs clientèles sont généralement des hommes, des femmes et quelques fois des enfants. Les membres du groupe Benkadi très organisées ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, avec lequel elles sont à leur premier prêt. Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 1 sac de sucre, 1 carton de thé, une importante quantité de condiments, une vane de cola et des sacs de fruits et légumes.

Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel 7 500FCFA qu’elles utiliseront essentiellement à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans les activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of various food items for re-sale

Achat de divers articles alimentaires

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
The committee named "The Hope" participates in the program called the "Committee of Enterprising Women" that consists of women that carry out lucrative work in order to improve their income and alleviate poverty. The ladies belonging to this committee are dedicated to diverse productive activities. They use their loan to buy more merchandise in some cases or supplies for making foods in the case of the ladies that are dedicated to food sales.

The activities that the ladies perform include selling silver jewels, selling clothes, running pantries and newsstands where they sell consumer staples for the home, selling foods, selling coal, recycling and selling natural remedies.

. The majority of the women long for a better future for their children. Therefore they double their endeavors to generate more income and to be able to offer their children the opportunity to study and to be able to apply for good employment.

The loan that they request will be invested in the purchase of ingredients for the making and sale of foods, the purchase of footwear for its subsequent sale, and the buying and selling of cosmetics, jewels, and coal, among others.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

El comité “La Esperanza” participa del programa llamado “Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras” que agrupa a mujeres que realizan una labor lucrativa con el fin de mejorar sus ingresos y aliviar la pobreza. Las señoras pertenecientes a este comité se dedican a diversas actividades productivas, utilizan el préstamo para comprar más mercaderías en algunos casos o insumos para la elaboración de comidas en el caso de las señoras que se dedican a la venta de comestibles.

Entre las actividades que realizan las señoras están las que venden joyas de plata, también las que venden ropas, otras poseen despensas y kioscos en donde venden artículos de primera necesidad para el hogar, otras venden comidas, una de ellas vende carbón, otra se dedica al reciclaje y por último una de ellas vende remedios naturales.

.La mayoría de las mujeres anhela un futuro mejor para sus hijos por eso se esfuerzan el doble para generar mas ingresos y poder brindarles posibilidades de estudiar y poder optar por un buen empleo.

El crédito que solicitan es para invertirlo en la comra de ingredientes para la elaboración y venta de comidas, compra de calzaD. para su posterior venta, compra y venta de cosméticos, joyas, carbón, entre otros.

loans.use: To buy merchandise and ingredients such as meat, milk, eggs, vegetables, oil, salt, cheese, starch, clothes, delicacies, cosmetics, baked goods and carbonated water.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en: Habiba A.  is a 44 year old married woman with two children. Habiba is a very courageous woman who has endured alot so that her two children could have a good education. Habiba is a small business owner from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. For the past 11 years, she has been selling children’s shoes at the large Central market in Dushanbe.  As the holiday season is coming, she would like to buy more merchandise at wholesale prices and sell them in her community. She is requesting a loan of 3400 Somoni ($1000 USD) for the term of 6 months to purchase a new supply of shoe inventory. This loan will help her continue to operate a successful business so that she can provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase shoes for her store

loans.name: Maria De La Luz

texts.es:
María de la luz inició el negocio para ayudar a su familia y superarse. Ante la falta de recursos económicos, tuvo que dar un paso para ser independiente y asi trabajar por su cuenta ya que lo único que sabia hacer era tomar fotografías pero a no era fotógrafa profesional sino empírica, poco a poco con la practica fue mejorando y tomo mas practica logrando establecerse en diversas ferias ofreciendo su servicio.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $850 que pagara en 6 meses ya que quiere empezar a tomar fotografía profesional en su casa con un jardín artificial así como comprar un impresora mas grande para las fotografías profesionales,
texts.en:
María de la luz started her business to help her family succeed. Given the lack of economic resources, she had to take a step to be independent and work on her own. The only thing she knew how to do was to take photographs, but she wasn't a professional photographer and only had informal training, but little by little with practice she was improving and with more practice she was able to establish herself in various fairs offering her service. She needs a loan of US $850 to be repaid in 6 months because she wants to begin taking professional photography in her house with an artificial garden and buy a bigger printer for the professional photographs.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a bigger printer

loans.name: Martha Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Martha tiene 40 años de edad, es la secretaria de su Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia y vive en la calle Elías Aguirre 453 interior B, distrito de Moche, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió secundaria completa y es costurera autodidacta, no continuó estudios superiores por falta de recursos económicos. Actualmente es separada por lo tanto madre y padre de sus hijos que aún son estudiantes.
Se dedica a la costura, confección de ropa deportiva, arreglos de vestidos, elaboración de disfraces y confección de artesanía. Todo lo realiza en el taller que se encuentra en su casa.
Con el primer crédito de S/. 300 cancelado en 4 cuotas, invirtió en su negocio comprando materiales.
Con este crédito de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará telas e hilos.
Martha sueña con poner un gran taller.
texts.en:
Señora Martha is 40 years of age, is the secretary of the "Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia" and lives on Elías Aguirre 453 interior B Street, district of Moche, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú. She completed high school and is a self-taught seamstress. She did not continue in advanced studies because she lacked the economic resources. Now she is separated and therefore is the mother and father of her children who are students. She works as a dressmaker, making sports clothing, repairing dresses, making costumes, and handicrafts. She does all of this in her shop which is found in her home. With the first loan of 300 soles which she repaid in 4 payments, she invested in her business, buying materials. With this loan of 500 soles ($175) which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy fabric and threads. Martha dreams of having a grand shop.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase fabrics and threads.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy es una mujer muy trabajadora que se esfuerza por mantener a su familia  libre de necesidades, por ello viene trabajando en una empresa donde producen alcachofas para luego exportarlas a los diversos países. También se dedica desde hace 5 años a la crianza de cuyes, ya que ahora de la misma forma como algunos de nuestros productos agrícolas son exportados, la demanda de cuyes también es una de las actividades más rentables, por los grandes pedidos que hay por su alto grado proteico. Sin duda ambas cosas son muy difíciles de realizar, sobre todo cuando hay que matar a los cuyes para poder venderlos. Este es su primer crédito con MFP y asume el compromiso de ser puntual con sus pagos, ya que es muy responsable con sus acuerdos asumidos. Nancy invertirá el dinero en la compra de cuyes de raza que eleven el costo de  venta, por el tamaño y peso que poseen.
texts.en:
Nancy is a hard-working woman who strives to support her family with their needs, which is why she works in a company producing artichokes for export to different countries. As well, she has raised guinea pigs for the past 5 years, as now much as some of our agricultural products are exported, the demand for guinea pigs makes this one of the most profitable activities due to the high demand for their high-grade protein. No doubt both jobs are very difficult to perform, especially when it comes to killing the guinea pigs in order to be able to sell them. This is her first loan with MFP and she promises to be punctual with her repayments, as she is very responsible. Nancy will invest the money in the purchase of purebred guinea pigs which will increase their resale value due to their size and weight.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy purebred guinea pigs

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is currently in the business of selling beans and rice at a resturant and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Susan is 28 years old and is widowed. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to expand her business and pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Yojana Karina

texts.es: Yojana Karina es soltera, y su negocio es hacer y vender tortillas en su casa y también entrega pedidos a otros negocios de venta de comida.  También se dedica a hacer tejidos a mano como lo son servilletas y manteles.  El préstamo lo necesita para comprar maíz y leña, ya que estos materiales han subido mucho de precio, y quiere comprarlos por mayor o por volumen para obtener un mejor precio y así tener más ganancias.  Ella por las tardes estudia y su deseo es superarse en la vida continuando con sus estudios
texts.en:
Yojana Karina is single, and her business is to make and sell tortillas in her home and to also deliver orders to other food sales companies. She also hand-makes textiles like napkins and tablecloths.

She seeks this loan to buy corn and firewood, as the prices for these items have risen substantially, and she wants to buy these wholesale or in bulk to obtain a better price and thus increase her earnings.

She studies in the afternoons and her desire is to excel in her life continuing with her studies.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials for her business making tortillas

loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
P. is 39 years old and a resident of Banteay Meanchey Province, Cambodia. She has three children: all of them are single and attend school. She is married to Riem who is a water pipe repairman. She has been providing jars for storing water throughout the village since 2005. She is famous for her jars, because she is good at making jars, a skill which she learned from her parents. She has gained a lot of customers and a better profit from this business.

Recently, P. wants to increase her income as the family's expenses require. So for that reason, P. is applying for a loan of US$ 500 to buy a jar mold and its accessories. She dreams of having a big jar shop and advanced degrees for her children.

loans.use: To buy a jar mold and its accessories

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Mrs. Erlinda S. is 62 years old, married and has no children. She is a resident of Roxas, Zamboanga del Norte.  She currently manages her sari-sari store and her husband does farming.  She's an active member of Paglaum MPC, and has already accessed financial support from Paglaum twice before.  Now she is applying for another loan to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store to help her husband.  She also hopes to save for their old age.

loans.use: To purchase grocery stock

loans.name: Battsetseg

texts.en: Battsetseg G. lives with her husband and three children in Arhangay province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Two of Battsetseg's children are university students, while her youngest daughter is a high school student. Although her husband runs a small carpentry shop, their income was not adequate to pay the family’s monthly expenses, which is especially burdensome with two children attending university. Hence, she decided to start a small private business to boost her family's income. She rents a small stall in the local shopping mall and sells wool and cashmere products. She frequently travels to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and purchases wool and cashmere products wholesale. In the future, she would like to diversify her business by opening a small cafeteria at the mall. She requests a loan to purchase more wool and cashmere products for her stall.

loans.use: To purchase more wool and cashmere products

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Madame Adama B. est une vendeuse des peaux de moutons.  Les peaux sont utilisées pour fabriquer les chaussures, donc elles sont très importantes dans la région.  Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 6 ans et elle est bien expérimentée.  Madame B. est mariée avec des enfants qu’elle va soutenir avec les revenus de son entreprise.  Elle habite à Diourbel, une petite ville rurale située 150 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale de Sénégal.
texts.en:
Ms. Adama B. is a retailer of sheep hides. The hides are used to make shoes, so these are very important in the region. She started this work six years ago, and she is very experienced. She is married and has children who she will support with the revenues from her enterprise. She lives in Diourbel, a small rural city located 150 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep hides

loans.name: Rena

texts.en:
Rena H. is a 28-year-old woman who has been in the bread making business for the last two years. She is married and has 2 children. Rena is a housewife and she decided to start her business to help her husband financially. Rena is a very good cook, and her bread is always popular among the local people.

Rena applied for this loan to improve her working conditions and purchase more flour to increase bread production.  Your loan can support this hardworking and brave woman.

loans.use: Purchase more flour and improve working conditions

loans.name: Ung's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ung Y. is a borrower who has been recruited to be leader of the group loan by other borrowers. She is 48 years old, a married woman and the mother of three children. All of her children are single and are employed as garment workers. She is a good housewife who cares for the children. The whole family’s daily expenses are contributed by Ung Y.’s husband who works as a civil service official. Ung Y. hopes to earn another profit by using her loan for capital in order to invest in a business as a merchandise trader in the village. 
The other borrowers who have joined this loan are:
S. P., who is 66 and earns a living providing small loans with a specific schedule repayment, will use the loan money for her service.
T. will use the money to accrue her business capital of selling vegetable.

loans.use: To invest in a business as a merchandise trader in the village

loans.name: Koko

texts.en:
Koko L., currently in the business of selling bread, is requesting a loan to purchase baking materials. Koko, who is 28 years old and married to a peasant, has two children who both attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bakery.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase baking materials.

loans.name: Maria Gemma

texts.en:
Maria Gemma P. comes from the village of Sto. Niño, Pagadian City. She is 44 years old, married, and has three adult children. She operates a little sari-sari (variety store) business, and has been engage in her business for years.

In 2009 Maria Gemma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 which will be use to purchase additional inventory. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plan to use the additional revenue generated from business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose E. is 40 years old and she is married with 5 children. She sells cooked foods and drinks. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks. She says thank to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Yesenia Elizabeth

texts.es: Yesenia Elizabeth M. D. C. resiD. en el municipio D. San Martin en la capital D. El Salvador. Yesenia vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos todos menores D. edad, Yesenia y su esposo luchan día a día para darle lo mejor a sus hijos brindándoles la educación escolar que ellos no lograron. Esta joven madre se desempeña en su propio negocio una panadería con ocho años D. experiencia, la cual ahora da trabajo a siete empleados y es la panadería más popular y demanda en la zona, el crédito que solicita Yesenia es para compra D. materia prima para su pan, ya que desea ampliar su producción para seguir expandiendo su negocio el cual es el pilar económico para familia C. M.
texts.en:
Yesenia Elizabeth M. D. C. lives in the municipality of San Martin in the capital of El Salvador. Yesenia lives in her own house with her husband and their four minor children. Yesenia and her husband struggle hard to give their children the schooling they did not get themselves. This young mother has eight years of experience in her own bakery, she now has seven employees and it is the most popular bakery in the area. The loan requested by Yesenia it to buy raw material for her bread as she wishes to increase the production in order to make her business grow as it represents the main income for the C. M. family.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw material

loans.name: Médéouye

texts.fr: Cette femme s’est spécialisée depuis 2004 dans le quartier Hédzranawoé à Lomé dans le commerce de charbons de bois. Ce commerce lui permet de se prendre en charge et de couvrir aussi les frais scolaires de son enfant. Actuellement son stock est presque épuisé ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle souhaite avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 40 sacs de charbons de bois ; ce prêt lui permettra aussi de couvrir les frais de transport à l’intérieur du pays.
texts.en:
This lady has been specialized in selling charcoal in the Hédzranawoé neighborhood in Lomé since 2004. This business allows her to support herself and also cover school fees for her child. Presently her stock is almost expended. This is the reason why she is hoping to have a loan from WAGES to buy 40 sacks of charcoal. This loan will permit her to cover the expense of transport from the countryside as well.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nueva Flor”  que esta ubicado de el distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 25 años de edad, estado civil casada y es madre de 01 hijo y tiene estudios de secundaria completa, vive en el centro poblado de Ocoña.

La señora trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace casi 01 año,  con un préstamo inicial de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles  para la compra de ganado menor. 

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo de S/. 1000.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de ganado mayor y menor para engorde, y venderlo luego de su asimilación en 4 a 5 meses, en las ferias de la zona.

Su mayor deseo es seguir trabajando para poder educar a su hijo.

A ella le gustan las facilidades de pago y sus bajos intereses
texts.en:
Mercedes belongs to the "Nueva Flor" ("New Flower") Community Bank in the district of Ilave, El Collao province, in the Puno region. She is 25 years old, married and the mother of one son, has completed her secondary education and lives in the town of Ocoña. Mercedes has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement for almost a year now, having received an initial loan of 500 PEN to buy small livestock. She is now asking for a loan of 1000 PEN to purchase small and large livestock for fattening, to be sold on at local markets after a 4-5 month period of development. Her greatest wish is to continue working and so be able to educate her son. She appreciates the ease of repayment and low interest rates.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Clapham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Bedan

texts.en:
Bedan has operated his butcher shop in Naivasha town for the last 2 years.  He is 30 years old and married to Naomi Wambui, they have 5 school going children.

He was intoroduced to KADET by his friend.  He paid his first loan well which he used to renovate his butcher shop with.  He is now applying for the second loan and he plans to buy sheep to rear so that by December the holiday season, he will slaughter and sell the meat.  This will give him a bigger profit compared to buying the meat for sale during that time bescause the prices will have gone up.

In future he still plans to continue with the butcher shop and enlarge it and even move to the town center.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy sheep for rearing which he will later slaughter for sale

loans.name: Nambar

texts.en:
S. is 21 years old and lives with his wife and one-year-old daughter in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is a university student and looks after their daughter at home. S. operates an ice cream and soft drink manufacturing business which was started by his father in 1996.

When the business was first started 13 years ago, the working capital was approximately 100,000 tugrug (~70 USD) but he and his father worked hard and today the working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD). S. took over the business in 2009 after his father retired and he wants to eventually build a small factory where he can produce more of his ice cream and soft drinks.

He works hard to improve his family’s quality of life and grow his small business. S. is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan in order to purchase supplies for his growing business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for his growing ice cream and soft drink business

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 36 years old and married with three children. She sells medicines and has been operating this business for the past five years. She is applying for a loan amount of N150000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Wava Muno Group Of Mukono

texts.en:
Christine N. is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a friendly and hard working lady who is married with a one-year-old child.  She also takes care of other orphans.

Christine has been operating a salon in Seeta for two years now and she is able to make 50,000 Ugandan shillings (about $27 U.S.) in profit per week. She is a good person with good customer care and her hope is to expand her salon further as well as her family having good health. Christine hopes this loan will boost her salon business enough so that she will be able to make more profit.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and hair pieces for a beauty salon.

loans.name: El Progreso 4 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Santa, 28, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, El Progreso (Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Santa and her husband live in Batey Santa Lucia with their three children, ages two, nine, and ten. A batey is a small rural community built by a sugar company to house their field workers. Bateyes are usually isolated with little or no access to electricity, potable running water, or medical services. Santa Lucia is particularly remote, and the community is quite small. Despite those difficulties, Santa has a successful business selling clothing to her community. With this loan, her second with Esperanza International, Santa plans on purchasing more merchandise and styles of clothing to sell to her customers.

Santa’s dream is to eventually be able to sell clothing in other communities. Before she had access to loans, this dream could never come true. Now, it is almost within reach as her business grows and she increases her profits. She will soon be able to pay for rides to other towns to expand her customer base. Santa’s dream for her family is that her children will all be able to go to college, an opportunity she never had. Thank you for lending to Santa and the El Progreso group!

loans.use: New and used clothing

loans.name: Anoch

texts.en:
Anoch is a 70-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Anoch has been selling coats and jackets since 1985. She is special in her work because she has good sales skills. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her business since it is the winter season.

Anoch has been a micro-credit client for eight years now and has always repaid on time. Her previous loans helped her improve her work by diversifying her merchandise and by expanding her stock.

When Anoch first started her business, she passed through some financial difficulties. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to be financially independent. In the future, she plans to keep on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her work

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: H. Julienne est née en 1962 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Julienne vit à Gbowèlè à Allada, depuis deux ans. C'est une veuve, ayant à sa charge quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Julienne assure seule les charges de la famille. Julienne n'a fait que l'école primaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Julienne mène comme activité, la vente des poulets et des escargots à Houègbo, à Sékou et Allada. Julienne mène cette activité depuis environs 14 ans, et s'approvisionne dans ces villages. Julienne a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Julienne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue d'augmenter son capital et de renforcer son activité. Ce qui lui permettra de subvenir, sans grande difficulté, aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
H. Julienne was born in 1962 in Allada, in Atlantique state in Bénin. Julienne has been living in Gbowèlè in Allada for two years. She is a widow and is raising 4 children, all enrolled in school. She is the only breadwinner for the family.

Julienne was only able to attend primary school. To support herself and her children, she sells chickens and snails in Houègbo, in Sékou, and in Allada. Julienne has been in this business for about 14 years and buys her merchandise in the villages. She has already been the recipient of 2 loans through ALIDé which were correctly reimbursed. She is requesting a third loan from ALIDé, to increase her working capital and bolster her business. This will allow her to cater for the needs of her family without too much difficulty.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 80 chickens and 4 baskets of snails

loans.name: Ana Lisbeth

texts.en:
Ana Lisbeth is 43 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and five daughters in Desemparados, San Jose, in the central valley of Costa Rica.

This is Lisbeth’s second loan with Fundacion Mujer. Her first was for 1,000,000 colones over twenty-four months and was dispersed in 2003. Lisbeth owned a corner store but, unfortunately, she had to close down the project because three mini-supermarkets opened in close proximity to her small store. The competition was too much and she was crowded out of the market.

Not to be deterred by the breakdown of her first enterprise, Lisbeth has since opened a beauty salon named “Lisbet’s Salon”. She has two years of experience working in salons and so, five months ago, she decided to open her own business. For the last five months, she has been working hard to keep the salon profitable.

Business hours are from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m., Tuesday to Saturday. Lisbeth works alone in her salon and offers a range of services including manicures, pedicures, haircuts and hair extensions. In a good month she earns 400,000; in bad months 160,000. The loan officer that has been working with Lisbeth describes her as hardworking with a fighting spirit and a strong history of punctual repayments.The current loan will be used to invest in her new business.

Lisbeth is applying for this loan to reinforce her working capital. She will use the loan to invest in general activities conducive to the growth of her salon. This last year was hard on business but in January her products and services have become popular in her community.

Specifically, Lisbeth will use this loan to buy a swivel chair to replace her old one in an effort to provide better service to her clients. She will also use the loan to purchase various products necessary for hair alterations, manicures and pedicures. Lisbeth says her only obstacle is economic.

loans.use: To buy beauty products and a swivel chair

loans.name: Flor De María

texts.es:
Flor de María Rodriguez vende ropa en el departamento de León ofreciéndola a diario a sus  clientes que visitan el mercado donde ella se encuentra e iniciando a trabajar todos los días desde las cinco de la mañana siendo muy trabajadora ya que vela por el buen funcionamiento de su negocio.
Atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en mercadería y para ello solicita un crédito para la compra de la ropa para continuar ofertándola y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y por ende mejorar las condiciones de su negocio.
texts.en:
Flor de María Rodriguez sells clothes in León department. She offers her wares daily to customers that visit the market where she's located. She starts her work daily at 5am and works very hard because she cares for the good functioning of her business. She is going through a phase now where she needs to invest in more stock items. She is asking for funding to buy clothing so that she can continue to offer it for sale thereby improving her living conditions and also improving her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en:
Epenesa L. is 53 and married with 6 children (ages 10 - 24).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Epenesa has many years of experience in this business.  Epenesa needs a loan of WST $1000 to rent land to raise additional crops.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Epenesa joined SPBD.  This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Epenesa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Epenesa L. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Silifa

texts.en:
Silifa lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Silifa is a trader: she sells cooking oil and other foodstuff. She manages the business with her children who assist her in the shop after school. She is hard-working and does all she can to improve her family life.

Silifa is requesting a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell as there has been an increase in demand. More sales will maximize her profit. She hopes to pay back promptly and she thanks all lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Yanet

texts.es:
Yanet es socia del Banco Comunal Manantial.
Yanet es conviviente, tiene 27 años y 2 hijos, Yanet vende fruta variada de manera ambulatoria en el mercado, además los días domingos viaja a las ferias en donde vende sus frutas.
Yanet necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de una mototaxi para que trabaje su esposo.
Los sueños de Yanet es mejorar su negocio y brindar una buena educación.
texts.en:
Yanet is a member of the Manantial Community Bank. She lives with her partner and is 27 years old with two children. Yanet sells a variety of fruit on foot in the market. Additionally, on Sundays, she travels to fairs where she sells her fruit. Yanet needs a loan of 2,100 soles which will be invested in the purchase of a mototaxi so that her husband can work. Yanet's dream is to improve her business and provide a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of a mototaxi so that her husband can work.

loans.name: Danelia Del Socorro

texts.es: Danelia es una señora muy dedicada al trabajo, tiene la edad de 37 años, procreo una hija, el cual la criado sola. Aun no ha logrado tener su propia casa, vive donde su mama, pero su anhelo es poder hacer su casa es por eso con el salario de su trabajo el cual se desempeña como secretaria desde hace nueve años, ha logrado comprar materiales de construcción como: bloques, arena, cemento para comenzar a construir su casa. Con este financiamiento quiere pagar la mano de obra el cual no cuenta con dinero en efectivo. Contenta por que lograra cumplir parte de su sueño. Sus planes es seguir laborando y seguir manteniendo estable su puesto. Ya que esta difícil el encontrar empleo hoy en dia.
texts.en:
Danelia is a woman who is very dedicated to her work. She is 37 years old and has one daughter, whom she raised alone. As she has not managed to have her own house, she lives with her mother. However her wish is to be able to have a house. It is for this that, with the wages from her job as secretary the past nine years, she has managed to buy construction materials such as concrete blocks, sand, and cement to begin constructing the house. With this financing, she would like to pay workers who do not accept money in cash. She is pleased because she has managed to complete part of her dream. Her plans are to continue working and continue maintaining her position, as it is difficult to find employment these days.

Translated from Spanish by Erin K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase part of the construction materials and pay workmen

loans.name: Renante's Group

texts.en:
Renante M. is from the village of Dalapang, Ozamiz City. He is 31 years old and the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Renante is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he grows corn and rice for sale. He has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Renante joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Renante has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2000 PHP from GDMPC. Renante is requesting a new loan of 2000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Renante from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Manelina

texts.en:
Manelina B. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to stock rice and beans to sell.  Manelina is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. 

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Azam

texts.en:
Azam Y., 36, owns a little grocery store in the local market where he sells a variety of goods. He works together with his brothers. Azam, together with his wife, have 3 children to support. Azam has asked for a loan of $1400 USD to purchase more grocery products, allowing him to expand his options and increase his inventory. He believes that this will allow him to reach a wider customer base so he can increase his income to help provide for his family. Azam looks forward to seeing the results of this investment and hopes that his family can become more economically secure for the future. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase the range of goods to sell

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa D. est une femme de 53 ans, elle est divorcée et vit avec ses deux enfants et ses deux petites filles. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de CENTRE2 dont elle est la secrétaire depuis le 8 janvier 2004. Elle développe un petit poulailler dans une partie de la cours de sa maison et ce nouveau prêt lui permettra d'augmenter sa production de poulets de chaire. Les bénéfices réalisés à partir de son activité contribuent à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Awa D. is 53 years old. She is divorced and lives with her two children and her two grand daughters. She is a member of the CENTRE2 Banc Villageois where she has been secretary since January 2004. Awa is developing a little chicken coop in her courtyard at home and this new loan enables her to increase her chicken production. The profits she makes from her activity contribute to an improved quality of life for her family.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her poultry business.

loans.name: Arsenia

texts.en:
Arsenia R. is from the village of  Valencia City. She is 56 years old. Arsenia is married and has 4 adult children. Arsenia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. Arsenia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Arsenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI. Arsenia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn B., from the village of Pagalongan, Wao, Lanao del Sur, is 43 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business venture selling generic medicines to local community members. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to to purchase additional generic medicines to sell, she is requesting her fourth loan for 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase more inventory and as working capital. Evelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Ken Sum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group consists of thirteen people who live Sameakki village, Takeo province. Mrs. Ken S., who was born in 1985, is the village bank president, having been selected by the other members. The members will use their portions of loan in varied ways to support their businesses.

Mrs. Ken S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Moreover, she is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Saren Kong, is a laborer.

Since her pig breeding is going well Mrs. Ken S. wants to expand it. So, to achieve this goal, she is applying for a loan to buy more piglets to raise.

Mrs. Ken S. is the mother of two children who are both too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores E. is from the town of Talibon. She is 33 years old. Dolores is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Dolores owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish and crabs at the market. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over 15 years. 

Dolores joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the third loan taken out by Dolores from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Nellie

texts.en:
Nellie S. is a widow who lives in Prk. 5, Brgy. New Barbacan, Roxas, Palawan. She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store.  Nellie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired to something better for her family. 

With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nellie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,000 helped her increase her monthly profit to PHP 30,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to buy more goods to sell in her general store so that she can continue to save up for future business expansion. Nellie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'Honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Virgen De La Misericordia Group

texts.es:
El Comité Virgen de la Misericordia es un excelente  comité conformado en fecha 31 de Mayo del 2.010, integrado por 20 mujeres de la Ciudad de Villeta. Este grupo se formó  gracias a que la Sra. Silvia D. se acercó a la asesora en una reunión de renovación de crédito que la misma tenía en la zona para averiguar acerca del Programa del Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, la misma quedó muy entusiasmada y muy ansiosa de poder trabajar con este programa y ahora ya se encuentran trabajando muy contentas en el 2° ciclo del Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
La Sra. Silvia posee un gallinero, muy bien montado, en el cual se dedica a la cría y engorde de pollitos para su comercialización, ya hace bastante tiempo que se dedica a este ramo y posee una buena clientela ya formada, teniendo en cuenta el consumo de la carne de ave por su economía en comparación a la carne vacuna.
Ella desea ampliar el negocio mediante la inversión en compra de mayor cantidad de pollitos, así también alimentos balanceados y equipos para el suministro de los mismos, para de esta manera incrementar sus ingresos y seguir creciendo en la producción animal.
texts.en:
The Virgen de la Misericordia Communal Bank is an excellent group, which was formed on May 13th, 2010. It is comprised of 20 women from the city of Villeta. This group formed thanks to Silvia D.. Silvia approached the advisor at a loan renewal meeting in her area to find out more about the Committee of Entrepreneurial Women Program. Silvia was very enthusiastic and eager to be able to work in this program. They are now very happily working in their second cycle with the Committee of Entrepreneurial Women Program. Silvia has a henhouse that is very well established. She raises and fattens chicks in order to sell them. She has worked in this field for quite a while. Taking into account the consumption of poultry instead of beef due to the economy, she now has good, fixed customers. She wishes to expand her business by purchasing more chicks. She will also purchase balanced feed and equipment to provide for the chicks. This way her income will increase, and her animal production will keep growing.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get chicks to fatten and raise and for balanced feed

loans.name: Rentsen

texts.en: Rentsen T. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in the Hovd province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife stays home and takes care of their children. Rentsen operates a photo and color printing business in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for three years and has gained much experience and a good reputation among his customers. He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a new photo printing machine for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new photo printing machine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and other essential materials

loans.name: 02.04.1.1 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en:
Thao N. T. (1) is a 37-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Thao is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 02.04.1.1 Nam Ngan (02.04.1.1 Nam Ngan).


Thao is widowed and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Thao owns & operates a clothing business.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general clothing services to local community members.  Thao has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,200,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2010, Thao joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Thao has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,963,500 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital.  This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Thao plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. T. Vien (3) is a 48-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  L. T. Xinh (4) is a 57-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


3.  T. T. Manh (5) is a 66-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  L. T. Loan (6) is a 54-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Thao N. T. (1) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Thao là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.04.1.1 Nam Ngan (02.04.1.1 Nam Ngan).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ quần áo thông thường cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Thao thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thao kiếm được khoảng 2.200.000 VND.  Vào 2010, Thao đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thao đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.963.500 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. T. Vien (3) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  L. T. Xinh (4) là 57 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  T. T. Manh (5) là 66 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  L. T. Loan (6) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco A. is 48 years old, married and has five school-aged children. He is from the village of Sinamar within the municipality of Roxas, Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Francisco raises pigs for fattening and sale. He has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Francisco joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Francisco successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. Francisco is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP that will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay tuition fees for his children.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
S. Norah lives in the Naguru neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has 6 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (orphans). Norah has a business of selling charcoal and bananas. She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Norah sells her products at the market, by means of retail.

Norah has requested for a loan of 1,200,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal and bunches of bananas. She also generates additional income through rental rooms.The main business challenge(s) for Norah include transportation and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and pay fees for the orphans. Norah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, monthly market dues, and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
N. Christine is 50 years old and lives in the town of Masindi in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. Christine has a bar, which she has run for two years. She also owns rental houses.
To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more drinks. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Christine hopes to generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. In the future, Christine hopes to own a depot shop.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks

loans.name: Batbold

texts.en: Batbold M. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and six-year old son in an apartment in Arhangai province in Mongolia. Batbold is a carpenter who produces a variety of wooden items, working from his home to fill orders. He has been in this business for six years, and has earned the loyalty of his customers because of the quality of his work and his outstanding service. He has been able to expand his business and hopes to establish and run a factory in the future. He is applying for this loan for 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy more timber for his business.

loans.use: To buy more timber

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
50-year-old Sylvia K. is now twenty years down the road in her poultry business in Nizam-Jinja. She has mostly been selling eggs and layer chickens. It was initially her husband's business, but with time she took over from him. She has four kids with her husband. They also have a goat selling business. Before she embarked on this business, Sylvia was more occupied doing subsistence farming. 

She says this business generates her about $756 a month, and with this loan she says she is going to buy more layer chickens that she will eventually resell.

loans.use: To purchase more layer chicken to resell

loans.name: Susana Tananko

texts.en:
Susana has been selling clothes in Naivasha town for the last year.  She is 33 years old, married to Tananko Ole M. and they have one child.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan to buy more clothes to sell. 

In the future, Susana hopes to grow her business and make enough income to send her child through school.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Maria Lucia

texts.es:
Maria Lucia T.: de 36 años tiene 2 hijos ella trabaja todos los dias vendiendo en el mercado municipal de su comunidad, ya que tiene que mantener a sus hijos porque estan en epoca escolar, ella vende frutas y berduras por mayor ella dice que nesecita invertir mas para elevar mas su ganacia ya que tiene mucha demanda de sus clientes, espor eso que ella solicita este credito para comprar frutas y berduras por mayor.
Agradece a Dios por haber conocido a fape porque es una institucion que le ha ayudado, sus sueños son tener un local donde vender sus frutas y verduras y tambien ir agregando otra clase de venta como por ejemplo venta de ropa tipica.
texts.en:
María Lucia T., 36, has two children.  She works every day selling in her community’s municipal market because she has to support her children who are school aged.  She sells fruit and vegetables at wholesale.  She says that she needs to invest more in order to increase profits because she has much customer demand.  This is why she is asking for this loan, to buy fruit and vegetables at wholesale.

She thanks God for having known Fape because it’s an institution that has helped her.  Her dreams are to have a locale where she can sell fruit and vegetables and also gradually add other kinds of sales like typical clothing, for example.
.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables at wholesale.

loans.name: Celfida Del Carmen

texts.es: Celfida del Carmen se dedica a la venta de tiste y frijoles cocidos. Esta no es la primera vez que solicita créditos a Fundación pues siempre se ha caracterizado, por ser una mujer muy responsable y luchadora. Ella inicio este medio de vida porque su Mama enfermo, fue con el paso del tiempo que ella se ha hecho cargo de este medio de vida. Ella tiene una gran variedad de clientes que llegan a solicitarle sus productos. Este crédito que solicita es para la compra de leña, frijoles, tistes, bolsas, maíz entre otros productos.
texts.en: Celfida del Carmen sells cooked beans as well as tiste, a typical drink made with cacao beans.   This is not the first time that she has asked for a loan with the Foundation.  She has always proven herself to be very responsible and a fighter.  She began this way of life because her mother became ill, and as time passed she has taken charge of it.  She has a great variety of customers who come to ask her for her products.  This loan will be used to buy firewood, tistes, bags, and corn, among other things.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es: Nelly, de 23 años; es una mujer trabajadora. Vive junto a su esposo José y su hijo Daniel, de 6 años. En una casa alquilada, ubicada en la localidad de Tapo. Desde joven comenzó a trabajar en la agricultura, de eso ya 7 años. En todo este tiempo pudo aprender las técnicas de cultivo como también los conocimientos para poder progresar y salir adelante. Sus principales cultivos constan de papa, arveja y habas, los cuales siembra en terrenos alquilados. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es poder compartir con su esposo las ganas de salir adelante, pues juntos salen a trabajar todos los días. Más le dificulta obtener su propio capital de trabajo, por los gastos que realiza en el alquiler anual de sus terrenos y los estudios de su hijo. Muy pronto cosechará 25 sacos de papa y 15 sacos de habas, con los que obtendrá una buena ganancia, y así incrementar sus ahorros con los que piensa muy pronto comprar su propio terreno. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “San jerónimo de Queta”, y este es el séptimo crédito con MFP, donde se siente realizada, pues el apoyo que recibe de su asociación le ayuda en la mejora de sus cultivos. Nelly, dentro de estos meses cosechará papa, por ello con el crédito está pensando comprar 2 bolsas de semilla de arveja y varios sacos de papa, los cuales esparcirá en sus terrenos agrícolas, después de su cosecha.
texts.en:
Nelly is 23 years old and a hard-working woman.  She lives together with her husband José and her 6 year-old son Daniel, in a rental house, in the town of Tapo.  Nelly has been farming since she was young.  She started 7 years ago.  Over the years she has learned farming techniques and also the knowledge needed in order to be able to make progress and get ahead.  Her main crops are potatoes, peas and beans which she grows on rented land.  What Nelly most likes about her work is being able to share with her husband the desire to get ahead since they both go out to work every day.  The most difficult part of her work is obtaining her own working capital and the expenses that she incurs in paying the annual rent on her land and her son's education expenses.

Very soon, Nelly will harvest 25 sacks of potatoes and 15 sacks of beans which will make her good profits and this will increase her savings with which she is planning to buy her own plot of land very soon.  Nelly belongs to the "San Jerónimo de Queta" community bank and this is her seventh loan with MFP where she feels fulfilled since the support that she receives from her association helps her to improve her crops.  In a few months Nelly will harvest her potatoes and is planning to use her loan money to buy 2 bags of pea seeds and several sacks of potato which she will spread over her farmland after her harvest.

loans.use: to buy pea seeds and sacks of organic manure

loans.name: Juvencia

texts.en:
Juvencia B., age 58, owns and operates a general store, where she buys and sells such items as canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap, and biscuits to members of the local community. In addition, her store offers plastic basins, rope by the meter, and gasoline by the liter. Juvencia has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month. She is from the village of Pelaez, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She and her husband have three grown children.
 
In 2008, Juvencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Juvencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and was employed as working capital. Juvencia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional rope and gasoline to offer for sale in her store. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Juvencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional rope and gasoline to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Mrs. Sem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eight people who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes so that it can improve their family's standard of living.
